@The_Crimson_Fucker But that doesn't disagree with my comment above.  I agree that nobody is born thinking they are in the 'wrong' body.  Gender expression is also forced on children as well almost from birth.  Parents are gentler with baby girls than with baby boys.  They dress them in different colours and give them different toys.  

It's only children with a sibling or cousin of the opposite sex who play with toys marketed to children of the opposite sex.  Sometimes I joined in with my brother assembling his train set and making the trains go while we changed the direction of the tracks.  We didn't have the room for a permanently assembled train set so it had to be assembled and disassembled each time we wanted to play with it.

replies.author: @lemsip207
replies.text: @annablueheaven1497 Too much gendering going on.  As a child I knew there were girl's toys, boys' toys and non gendered toys.  But over the decades more toys were sold as girls' toys that were non gendered toys such as art and craft kits.  Musical instruments are considered to be boys' toys but when I was a child only a guitar was labelled a boys' toy.  Drums, maracas, tambourines, recorders and keyboards were for both boys and girls.  There has been a campaign to stop gendering of toys in shops and now The Entertainer chain of toy shops stocks toys by type not gender.

replies.author: @The_Crimson_Fucker
replies.text:
‚Äã@lemsip207 
"It's only children with a sibling or cousin of the opposite sex who play with toys marketed to children of the opposite sex."
That's just plainly wrong. I was an only child and I loved playing with Barbie dolls. My parents tried to dissuade me - but that's only because they knew other people would laugh at me(which they did and I didn't care). I also loved playing with toy guns(right up until they were banned) and army men(my favorite "toy" ever is a box of extra-small army men I got as a gift).

I don't think "gender expression" is "forced" on children. I think people generally raise their children according to what they think would be best for them, and their sex obviously matters in that. Boys and girls are different, what they're suited to is different and how they'll be treated is different - so it makes sense to prepare them for all that.
In the same way, how people raise their kids is a direct reaction to how they were raised and what sit as "right" to them - so these traditional roles self-perpetuate.

As to the rest of it, there's a lot of childless weirdos going around designing marketing and programs for children having no idea what the fuck they're doing.
The latest rash of children's movies is a perfect example of this, there's a reason why they compare so terribly to movies from when we were growing up despite those often containing far more adult subtexts and "easter eggs"(remember the entire category of content "for the dads").

The fact is most people, and as a matter of absolute certainty, all children _have none of this anywhere in their minds_ until someone makes it a point to repeatedly expose to and attempt to indoctrinate them either way. This goes for loopy lefties and it goes for the kinds of people who go around saying women should wear bath-towels on their heads and men need to go and die for Allah - and both groups are exclusively motivated by the profits of those who organize this kind of mental illness.

Lastly, as to the "changing of gender expression from culture to culture" it is far less significant than you'd think. Most cultures share the majority of their concepts in term of basic gender roles and the core of the rest of "gender expression". Particular details change, obviously, but the core is relatively consistent. Where we do see substantial differentiation is according to material and political conditions - cultures which are wealthier and freer are less strict on these matters and more fluid when market demands need to be met.
Conversely cultures which are poorer and more tyrannical are both stricter and less adaptable to meet material realities.

And this applies to all areas of society, not just the place of men and women.

P.S.: As to retail, this "thinking" changed when people realized that customers were more likely to suffer higher prices _and_ be more tolerant when buying from a woman.
It's a matter of extensive documentation by now that people are both more amicable and trusting of women, conversely more respectful and deferential to men. This is why so many stores have men roaming the isles guiding and informing customers while women are there at the registers to take their money.

From my work experience in the service industry, all of our female waiters always got bigger tips and were far more likely to be forgiven when they messed up - and the prettier and/or nicer they were the more this scaled. Conversely the male staff rarely saw tips but also rarely saw uppity customers and arguing - to the point that when we didn't have a male waiter on shift one of the bartenders would fill-in for problem tables. Tables would calm down the moment their waiter got switched to a guy, but also tips would dry up as well.

replies.author: @lemsip207
replies.text:
@azraelbatosi That's the case in fee paying schools and the public or state schools in better areas.  In poorer areas children are taught to forget about themselves and their loved ones and put the 'greater good' first which is really just the elites.  The individual doesn't count.  It's Abrahamic thinking and the JOY (Jesus first, others second, yourself last) acronym secularised.  There are schools in poorer educational authorities near me where that is how children are being taught.  They are being taught about death studies and sacrifice.  That led to an outbreak of suicides in Bridgend County in South Wales. Look up UK Column on this.  There has been more of a move towards this in late 90's from then on. Left wing groups on Facebook are full of sacrificial people brought up by working class parents who were often religious as well.  It's all about the 'greater good' and the following the 'science' and not about the individual to them.  It's no longer about me, myself, my family, my friends and my mates at work but about my betters.  

A former friend of mine was brought up in Bridgend County which covers Maesteg, Tonteg and Bryngarw.  He is a shell of a human being because he wasn't getting the emotional support at home and was being brainwashed in school where teachers actually bullied weak minded pupils and encouraged other pupils to bully them as well.  I've tried to help him put himself first and stand up for himself sometimes because you can't help other people from an empty emotional well.  He has become a masochist.  He will splash the cash on friends because it's not just about helping them out but draining his own bank balance.  There's no thought going into the copious presents he showers on friends because he thinks if he buys enough rubbish some of it will be appreciated but each unwanted present has a negative not neutral effect on the recipient.  He doesn't have a clock on the wall or mantelpiece, watch or alarm clock so has to rely on other people to remind him of the time at home and when out and about and to ask people to give him a wake up call in the morning if he has a morning appointment.  He did eventually find an alarm clock under a pile of other belongings but no batteries for it but he never has the time to buy new batteries. He won't complain to his landlord about a door bell only being heard downstairs in a large shared house he used to live in because to him that is 'service to self' only.  He won't complain to his present landlord about the water pressure to his toilet being low so you have to wait half an hour to be able to flush the toilet again as he sees that as 'service to self' only.   

So I try to appeal to his selfless nature in trying to change the self defeating behaviour by suggesting all this present giving is a way of controlling other people and that other people living in the same building or visitors are affected by not having an upstairs doorbell and low water pressure to the toilet.  Doesn't work as the other people in the building and visitors are of a lower priority to him than certain women in his life.  All the visitors other than myself are male so I and they are of lower priority to him than the friends who are house bound that he visits.  Sometimes you have to try and change the self defeating or selfless behaviour instead of the self defeating or selfless mindset if changing that mindset doesn't work.

Someone I know in Caerphilly removed her remaining children from state schools when her eldest left school and she found out about what her children were being taught with these scenarios.  She also said various organisations were sending representatives into schools to brainwash children with their propaganda.  One of them is Stonewall.  It's led to masochism and self harm.  Turning children in these schools into shells of human beings if they are emotionally neglected at home as well.   They will remain shells of human beings all their lives.

replies.author: @beowulfsrevenge4369
replies.text:
@xd-hc8cc Capitalism with out checks and balances can end up being just as terrible as communism. Just look at the the early years of the industrial revolution. Horrible things were done in the name of profit. Child labour on a scale its hard to believe. Short or almost non existent wages. Company towns that literally owned the people who worked there through the debt accrued while living and working for the Company. The list literally goes on and on into an exhibition of the worst things humans are capable of. 

But the capitalism we have today is NOT unfettered capitalism. We have labour laws to prevent the mistakes made in the past. We have safety regulations on manufacturing and job sites. There's unions that support and actively defend the rights and benefits of the workers in them. We have learned from the mistakes made in the past. 

Is modern capitalism with out faults? Absolutely not. There are still greedy powerful people willing to cut corners to make extra profits. But that will never end. Those people will always exist no matter what government is in place. The importing thing is that things can change for the better in our governmental and economic system. Things have changed. People in a communist country do not have the same rights as those in a democratic country. 

Your worried about pollution? I agree it's a problem and not a small one. Capitalism is responsible for some of it. But not all of it. China is one of the most polluted countries in the world. The west regularly exports our waste to them and let them take care of it. The reason? They do not have the same regulations on pollution or working environments as in a democracy country. Big corporations have moved some manufacturing out of the US to other countries because of the lack of working regulations. There trying to make as big a profit as possible and don't care about its effects in that third world country that has workers right or safety regulations. Should the American or western companies be held accountable? Yes. The countries that allow those factors to be made should also be held accountable. 

Now on starvation. My point was that the people in the USSR and CCP were purposely starved. The ability of the people to farm was purposely undermined and destroyed. The food available was taken away. Look up the Holodomor and The Great Leap Forward. That's a small taste of the horrors purputrated under communism. 

Go do some actual research and some critical thinking on these subjects.

replies.author: @otakumangastudios3617
replies.text:
@lucymartyr4364 I feel like everyone is so confused and what the true definition of gender is. Growing up, gender was just something on your birth certificate, and therefore your pronouns. In fact, there was a lot of work towards trying to decipher personality types and interests and temperaments from gender itself, and making alternative genders you can convert to is reaffirming the old-fashioned ideas of yesteryear, that girls want to be pretty and soft, and boys want to be tough and dirty and not care about their clothing. While I disagree with a lot of baby boomers, this was definitely something they fought towards, to abolish all stereotypes from being associated with gender. I can say for sure I myself as someone who had gender dysphoria as a kid as well, I feel like I was a boy so much, although I was afraid to acknowledge that to anyone, as it was pre 2016. I felt free or feeling like a boy rather than a girl, due to our society telling us that being a girl needs to be wearing a pink skirt, talking with a certain intonation, loving certain topics, painting your nails, hating potty humor, etc.

it seemed to me the only alternative was boy, which seem to fit more with my personality type, as especially back then, I was really into big robots, I still am now, but in a different way, as in I'm more into the gundams rather than the transformers, as well as I was a huge fan of marvel at the time, and science fiction in general. I've always loved crude jokes, jokes that were unladylike for a girl to ever say or be interested in, loved climbing trees and getting dirty not giving a crap to what my clothing looked like in terms of fashion and just wanting to be comfortable, although at that time a very specifically wanted to wear boys clothes, because of my dysphoria. At this point I just wear whatever, I just want to be physically comfortable. I felt even better and more like myself when I realized I can be feminine and be a girl and like all these things that I described before, and since the word feminine is directly derived from female, basically attributing personality type as being masculine or feminine is implying gender stereotypes, that a personality type can be tied to a gender. The world doesn't work that way, as much as it seems. To me it's not right that there's a voice section in girls section in the toy aisle, I should be all mixed together and not made into such a binary, since only binary is our genitalia.

You just sound like what would've once been called a Tomboy. It's like saying because some women are interested in automotive mechanics, or some men are interested in knitting the gender stereotypes don't exist, but they do, the majority of males tend towards different interests than the majority of females.

replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã this is how things should have been, and how I thought things were going. I thought we were finally getting into the mindset of "boys can play with dolls, girls can play with trucks, who cares" but nope. now we're just enforcing old fashion gender roles with a progressive coat of paint. if your son plays with dolls and wants to dress as a princess, he cant be an effeminate boy, he must be a girl and need hormones and surgery. and if you don't fit into either of them, you have to find another hyperspecific label for yourself. I'd be happy to never hear the word "gender" for the rest of my life ffs. I really don't care how people express themselves if they mind their own business about it. it becomes an issue when it's labeled and the label is treated like some sacred category that everyone must tread carefully around lest they say the wrong thing and become an evil villain for it. 

I honestly think that there's a lot less people than you'd think who would genuinely be offended by men wearing dresses and women wearing suits if they minded their own business, outside of the super religious/conservative older generation. it's the way the community acts and imposes themselves in the name of "activism" that ironically makes them hated. their optics are so horrendous, they have to keep people in line by social backlash at this point when all they had to do was just keep to themselves and the culture would have grown more accepting organically; when the bubble finally grows to large, they're going to fall hard. I feel bad for the normal gay people because support for gay rights is actually going down because of these nutcases.

replies.author: @sneedcat88
replies.text:
I wasted time writing a whole multi paragraph comment only for it to be deleted by youtube..great. but I think instead of all this hyperlabeling can't we just have biological sex and let people do whatever they want. who cares if a boy wants to play with dolls or a girl wants to play with trucks. I was one of those girls, and I grew up with a relatively masculine mindset of being stoic but like to look and act quite feminine. almost no one is a perfect fit for any one role.

The community is ruining themselves with their horrible optics. Very few people would have a problem if it was just crossdressing, it's the way they impose themselves on everyone's life in the name of "activism", and make people walk on eggshells just to not incur the wrath and social backlash. all they had to do was mind their own business and the social climate would have slowly progressed organically. with what they're doing now, eventually the bubble will grow too large, and they'll fall hard; people don't like having ANYTHING forced on them. support for gay rights is going back for the first time in years because of these nutcases, I feel bad for the normal gay people out there.

replies.author: @otakumangastudios3617
replies.text:
@gouachepottwo7537 that's not their point. Their point isn't to say that people who identify as asexual aren't normal human beings, their point is, it's quite normal for any organism to fluctuate in their level of desire for sexual intercourse. It is not considered common nor normal to be constantly horny, that is something that our society has pushed upon us, and I think it's strongly connected to the extremes of the sexual liberation movement of the '60s and '70s, basically, there's a reaction to extreme prudishness of the 40s and 50s, and then now it's devolved into the complete opposite, that we're all pressured to feel and think in a constantly super duper snooper horny way, as if we're so desperate to reproduce. The thing is, especially humans, aren't that way. You may even be horny all the time, but not put those hormones upon everyone else. That's not what being sexual is about, contrary to popular belief. It took me a very long time to realize that myself, who also at some point identified as asexual.

Something I've noticed as someone who identified as a sexual, and when I've talked to other people who identified as asexual, is that we all share one common thing: we felt imposed upon by our society to have stronger sexual feelings outside of our personal boundaries then what felt healthy or normal for us personally. We are told it's normal to be constantly thinking about how someone is attractive, or wanting to bang someone. That's not natural or normal, that's social, and it's not a healthy way of living. It is healthy to have your sexual inclinations fluctuate, and that might mean feeling most of the time not horny, or that might mean feeling more all the time, but that doesn't mean also if you're horny all the time, that doesn't mean you have to automatically be talking about oh my gosh I'm so horny or watching p*** or be interested in banging your friend or a random person on the street or think a particular celebrity or character is super attractive. It just means you have strong sexual inclinations, but you choose to preserve them for when it would be holy and sacred and not to be fleeting and vain in your sexual feelings. Especially as youngsters, we're often times convinced that, oh it's normal to feel sexual feelings! To the point that we feel like that's the only way to live, while the point of the sexual liberation movement was to keep kids from feeling ashamed of their sexual inclinations, it's led us to feeling ashamed for not feeling sexual enough. Again, when I've talked to other people who has ever identified as asexual, they had the exact same feelings about this. It seems like it's not so much that there's a bunch of asexual people, there's a bunch of people that have been heavily affected by our society's unreasonable expectations when it comes to sexuality.

replies.author: @Sanakudou
replies.text:
@PCGameplayism  I haven‚Äôt done a political alignment test in years but I know it was pretty close to yours, probably for similar beliefs on free healthcare. One thing I try to remind conservatives about is that if we‚Äôre not going to be like the left and abort babies even when we know they‚Äôll be disabled, we better bloody have a system in place to assure their survival and medical care. 

From what I understand about American health care, by being born disabled I wouldn‚Äôt be able to get insurance and afford any medical care. I talk to people with the same disability as me in the US and hear how they‚Äôre always having blocks of time where they‚Äôre without essential medicine because they struggle to afford it. That on it‚Äôs own would disable them further and make holding a job down impossible, so then they just end up on welfare, accessible healthcare actually helps the sick hold down jobs and participate in the economy like everyone else.

I‚Äôm in Australia and very much like our half public half private system. If you have money you‚Äôll always choose private because you get doctor choice and no wait times, which results in less of a wait time for those who can‚Äôt. The fact the government doesn‚Äôt have to cover EVERYONES healthcare helps the federal budget. 

My one gripe with the system is the disability pension. It‚Äôs great in the sense it makes some healthcare absolutely free and medications cost drastically less, but these features incentive staying on the pension. A disabled person can often only work a simple job, if you only earn minimum wage, which is more than the pension, leaves you with a higher cost of living, you‚Äôre better off on the pension. 

I think those disability health cost perks should continue post-pension till you reach a certain income bracket. It means disabled people can live a more fulfilling life working while still getting the helping hand they need, ultimately it‚Äôd cost taxpayers less than financially trapping them on the pension. There‚Äôs a lot more to think about regarding healthcare issues and I think being an absolutist about either free or no free healthcare is just a way to dismiss dealing with the complexities of the issue and narrowing down policies that are moral and fair for both those in need of these services and those who don‚Äôt/who provide the tax money that funds it. An individual country‚Äôs economy is also a really important factor in what policies are needed/are possible, as is uncontrolled/mass immigration.

replies.author: @Lorkisen
replies.text:
‚Äã@PCGameplayism To be fair it "Free Healthcare" barely even works in Norway. The waiting lines for treatment are atrocious, and the rationing of the limited "free" resources meant that patients will have to suffer from medical conditions that lead to a severe reduction in quality of life or productivity for months and potentially years because it is not deemed sufficiently "urgent". Most of the time it is faster just to go to a private clinic to get tested and treated. 

Example: Your doctor suspects you have severe Sleep Apnea, you can choose to wait months for a test at the public hospital, or you can pay (ca. 900USD) a private clinic to get checked with almost no waiting. Now you have the diagnosis, choose again if you'll wait potentially months to get the "free" CPAP machine, or buy one yourself (ca. 900USD) to finally get quality sleep, reduce your risk of Depression, Heart Disease, etc. Immediate treatment means an improvement in quality of life and productivity. 

You'd think that this would be tax deductible after all by getting treatment privately, you are not extending the waiting line, you are less likely to be on disability which would be a direct drain on the public resources, to need surgery to deal with the health consequences of Sleep Apnea, but no. Common Sense has no place when the goal is "equal access to healthcare for all". And I'm only talking about the effect on the person with the untreated medical condition, if you extend the analysis to the patients' relations, then this policy makes even less sense.

replies.author: @RoganGunn
@RoganGunn
replies.text:
"Utopia" literally means "nowhere" in Greek, and was a pun by Sir Thomas More in his book of the same name in 1516.

More's treatise was "about an imaginary island enjoying the utmost perfection in legal, social, and political systems", the whole point of which was to show that such a place cannot exist and any attempt to achieve one was folly.

So anyone who says they want to, or even can, achieve a "Utopia" is by very definition a fool. They're literally trying to create a "nowhere."

replies.author: @tiikerihai
replies.text:
He's not wrong, the theoretical ideal communism is an anarchist utopia. The only problem is that "theoretical ideal communism" doesn't exist in real life, much like the "perfect man" does not. The method for achieving communism doesn't work either - it supposes that you are to create a government that controls with absolute authority every aspect of day to day life and the economy, then at some point this government is supposed to willingly disband to usher in the utopia. 
You don't need to have PHD in quantum physics to figure out that the incentive for the government to follow that course of action doesn't exist while the incentive not to do so does, which means every attempt at implementing communism ends up being totalitarian socialism until it implodes under the weight of corruption.

replies.author: @otakumangastudios3617
replies.text:
@quiewy3436 I'm sorry to say this, as someone who had gender dysphoria in Middle school, I have to say I must disagree with you. Our society has decided that gender is a social construct, gender and itself is not. What we consider masculine and feminine absolutely is, which is a huge huge problem. What we need to deconstruct is not gender itself, rather the societal expectations of each gender, as each gender does not have a personality type nor does it define who You are. I'm saying this as someone who felt like transgender boy in Middle school, although I was very closeted about it at all times. I feel like there's only two options, either I was a girl and liked pink mini skirts, gossiping in a valley girl intonation, makeup, painted nails and hated flatulence humor, or I was a boy, who by my definition at the time and by many people's definitions these days, was someone who was strong, had a full spectrum personality, liked heavy duty subjects, cyberpunk, dystopia in stories, not caring about fashion and only wanting to be comfortable in one's clothing and believing in only practicalities. This is what I thought being male versus being female was, this fit more with my personality, so I believe that therefore must be a boy. I did feel free or believing this, rather than fitting in a box that I didn't, until I realized that I didn't need to put myself in a box at all, that masculinity and having a more rugged personality do not go hand in hand, having a rugged personality and having a rugged personality does. There's nothing Butch about me or tomboyish about me, I'm simply me, Aki, the woman I'm proud to be, there's no makeup not even eyeliner, hates glittery things and loves fart jokes.

Because of this, I believe it's strongly and healthy too be changing one's gender identity simply because of one's personal interests. We are actually giving in to Old world stereotypes of gender that the hippies in the 60s tried so hard to abolish, so kids like us could finally feel free to be who we are without feeling like our personality traits did not fit our gender, but yet here we are, reversing all of that. There's a lot of things I did not agree with that they did at the time, but it was ultimately to a better cause.

replies.author: @29-arnavsamant97
replies.text: @otakumangastudios3617 see but the expectations are rooted to an extent in biology. While it's stupid to say boys can't like pink, boys liking guns or trucks is mostly biological.

replies.author: @otakumangastudios3617
replies.text: @29-arnavsamant97 not anymore biological than for girls. In fact, psychological studies have proven that *both* boys and girls, suffer greatly if they grow up without violent simulating situations or games, such as Nerf battles, wrestling, the likes. It's been found that children that did not engage in these activities, regardless of their gender, usually grew up to be more irritable, have mood swings, and more likely going to have a bout of rage as adults, and tend to be more snappy and less patient. Scientists believe it's because of the playful act of pretend aggression, that it somehow correlated with actual aggression in the future. So, you are correct, it's biological, but it's biological for both men and women to have the inclination to be aggressive. Believe it or not, most girls have had the chance to dispose of their energies that way, but those who don't, grow up to be more irritable and have anger issues correlated to lack of playful violence. It's not masculine or boy like to want to have a Nerf battle, it's simply natural for a child to want to pretend there is some sort of social conflict that needs violent confrontation, of course they don't think of it that way, scientists don't know why this happens, but it seems to be directly correlated with actual violence, and such play prevents someone from being potentially violent in the future.

replies.author: @contemplateeternity8398
replies.text:
@PHUCKyoutube689 There is a lot to unwrap in your comment.
First, you misread me. My approach would be teaching kids (and adults) self reflection techniques, not enforcing PC-culture. 

Second, I understand your frustration with these kids telling you what you can and cannot say. Obviously, they need to learn to not take themselves so seriously because you cannot control what others say or think about you. However, these kids have been bullied by society telling them they can‚Äôt be the way they strongly feel they are, so the natural first response will be standing up and asserting their right to be how you are. Your doing the same right now since they are basically giving you a dose of your own strategy which clearly doesn‚Äôt work long term. If you let it get to you by getting upset like so many on here, you will just propitiate a cycle. It‚Äôs a sad place to be, but it‚Äôs your choice.

I realize your doing it for the kinship you feel with those who feel the way you do, but shitting on others is always gonna come back to kick you in the nuts one way or the other karmically. But totally your choice.

Lastly, your note on emotional trauma doesn‚Äôt exist says a lot about your own trauma. Emotional trauma is so normal in our society that you think it‚Äôs normal or natural (this reflects to your views on bullying). Any time a figure of authority or a group of your peers used fear to motivate you as a kid, and you accepted that motivation, you have accepted emotional trauma and it is the source of anxiety for you and many others and is why so many are deeply unhappy and unfulfilled. You probably have a very pessimistic view of the world and people in general as a result and believe that everyone deep down is self-serving. It‚Äôs easy to believe that when we came out of survival evolution, but there is deeper core of truth underneath which only you can find in yourself through deep self reflection into your own actions and thought patterns and the underlying reasons, not stopping until you have a clear and consistent answer. It‚Äôs a long road and you may lose friends over it, but your strong enough to push through and find the truth of what‚Äôs going on in this world when no more anger is within you. Good luck on your journey, friend.

replies.author: @folding_chable
replies.text:
‚Äã@Hugh Mongous The problem is people who do think they already have all of the answers usually don't want to be taught otherwise lol. They reject any contrary information as falsehood. If they already know everything about a topic, and they encounter information that contradicts their understanding, then that information must be wrong. 

The point where you become a mature adult is when you find yourself in that situation and can say to yourself "okay, maybe I was wrong before, I should explore this more". But for a lot of people that doesn't happen until they're in their 20's, because our brains are still developing at that point. For some people it never happens at all, and they just peak mentally in their teens. 

I think you've kinda hit the nail on the head by bringing up the effect of what previous generations teach the youth, but that doesn't only apply to boomers. Gen Z didn't come to form these kinds of opinions in this video entirely on their own, they were taught a lot of this by millenials and Gen X'ers. I know that because I am a millenial myself and I watched it happen. The people around my age were the ones who really lit a fire under the ass of the progressive movement in relation to things like gay rights in the 2000's, which absolutely needed to happen, but clearly it lead to other less positive outcomes.

Namely it created a culture where intolerance of any kind became viewed as a cardinal sin to be stamped out with prejudice, and victimhood is rewarded with praise and attention on a societal scale. On the face of it that might seem positive, but the end result has been a culture where people are afraid to speak their minds lest someone take their word as "intolerant" and attempt to stamp them out. Where people are incentivised to compete for victim status because they can see how beneficial the attention that brings could be for them, and now they often do this for reasons that are less than ethical. 

And all the while that is going on, you've got millenials going into their 30's in that environment. Either fully embracing the aforementioned culture through "social justice" ideology, or too afraid to question it. And these are the people who are tasked teaching the next generation, so what are they going to teach them? Well, as it turns out, mostly more of the same.

imo it's not any one generation who is to blame for this. The problem is ideological. It started with good intentions, seeking to fix problems that existed long before the boomers. But somewhere along the way certain people's bad intentions, those who would use it to silence legitimate political opposition and abuse people's empathy for their own personal gain, turned it into a cultural poison.

replies.author: @markschmidt9142
@WifeyReviews
replies.text:
@folding_chable  Glad you beat me to the punch, I agree with what you say, (I think) but I would have put it differently, while we can and should blame the boomer generation, we must also blame what they raised up, (as a millennial) and it has to do with responsibility, virtue and the outcomes of all things. We can blame parents for not doing a better job, sometimes we should less, and sometimes more, but we must also blame the kid. When the kid grows into an adult, you have to, at some point, start blaming him, despite his upbringing and shortcomings, even if he wasn't given much of a chance, because someone always has it worse, and at some point time will turn you into an adult of sorts, and it can be a childish adult, who refuses to think for oneself, refuses responsibility, uses excuses like "I was never taught any better, I'm poor so I'll resort to lying and stealing!" or whatever excuse you can think of, but at some point you have to hold the adult accountable, too, deservedly, I'd say, or else everyone keeps shifting blame to the start point, and at that point we may as well say "So the first humans should have elected for self deletion so we could avoid all of this" So everyone should be blamed according to how much they should.

I've said that people, including our generation, generally lost good fundamental values, they don't have it. So we don't think for ourselves, or even know what good is, we say "morality is subjective" because we want it to be true, rather than believing or thinking it to be true, truly. Communism and socialism, (being the path to communism) is a bad idea on paper and worse idea in practice, the fact that many cannot see it as such just speaks to the perverted values of people. In high school, I was flabbergasted when I asked a teacher what would she think of my paper if I made it plainly bad and low effort since she said it was "subjective and not gradable" (paraphrased) and she said "Well, then that'd be your paper" a sort of waving away the fundamental problems of not having an objective parameter within which to test essays and papers, I was very surprised about that because she was our teacher that was going to grade our papers anyways, despite her professed values of "it's subjective you can't really rate it" I do think the discussion of how and what and why and should art in its various forms matters, but most people do not even have a fundamental understanding of a lot that involves the world, so when people are asked about or to think of other topics, they cannot understand it, they do not understand the basic building blocks much less what comes after, I suppose, at the risk of sounding like a elitist asshole.

In my work, I work with younger, (a lot of older and younger) people, including younger generation Z kids, one of them, who's name I'll change to Robert, who is a lot younger than me, is a friend of mine and I like him, and his (changed name) close friend Lisa, who is a lesbian woman. I'd consider her a friend, too but maybe more of an acquaintance. He's smart for his age, he listens without just giving a knee jerk reaction, really thinks about things, I try to listen to him and give advice where relevant, and he cracks me up. He calls me wild, (not in a hostile way) says I have a strong personality, (heard that before, along with wild) and asks me questions like "So, do you ever think like, should I do think or think this or how will people of my (race) community think of it?" he's a thoughtful guy. He also cracks me up because he'll tell me things I forget. "Yeah, you say some shit, like the other week when you were going off on masks being communist" because he'll say something that sounds like something I'd say but I don't always recollect actually saying it. That and one day he was telling me about how him and Lisa shared the same woman in the same night, (but on separate bedroom moments) while her presumably husband watched them, so it was a cuckold and bull moment, and then he woke up the next morning and just contemplated life.

'course he did pick up a lot of lingo the youngins' use nowadays like 'bet'. I do like him and Lisa, but a lot of the younger generations I dislike, too much time on phones, little to say/do/think or them playing high school social games. Virtue signaling.

We live in very different times. One thing that I always thought odd about that is some people would defend it, "well, the previous generation always complains about the newer, one, so, ha, nothing changes!" No, something can continually get worse.

Honestly, I just hate everything about the phrase "you're valid! üíñüíÖ". 
It just sounds like something a predator would say to groom someone, for just how manipulative it sounds. On top of that, it's just so petty. It's basically rewarding someone for nothing. "Omg ur valid! And that's ok because you exist! x3". 
congratulations, you're a living breathing organism belonging to the human species, amongst 8 billion people. Woah! How special! 
Have you achieved anything in life to be proud of?... are you setting yourself some big goals to follow? What's have you accomplished?...nothing? You're just patting yourself on the back for living in a post modern first-world country in a middle class society, imagining your life is under constant threat from dead ghosts that are hardly relevant? You survived another day of having basic responsibilities to fulfil? Wow, lame.

And look, I'm not mister perfect who's done everything, and has golden trophies for every sports, arts, or grade A* on every exam paper I've ever had. And im probably pretty incomincompetent in some aspects. But I don't congratulate myself for living life as it is. Because I have set myself targets I want to achieve, to become better. On top of that, I don't need validation from strangers I've never met, to tell me "im perfect just the way I am", because that doesn't encourage one to challenge themself and improve themself. And living life without adversities to overcome, leads one to live in a bubble to construct adversities irrationally. I am content with who I am, and even whe I'm not, I know better than to find support from strangers, depending on circumstances.

replies.text: Pretty sure that's communism or fascism since both can and have done that. Socialism is a political and economic theory of social organization which advocates the means of production, distribution, and exchange should be owned or regulated by the community as a whole. replies.author: @dorians.9872
replies.text:
@TheGooseIsLoose9000 "By 1921, many Italian workers and peasants were unionized and had their own political organizations. With demonstrations, strikes, boycotts, factory takeovers, and the forceable occupation of farmlands, they had won the right to organize, along with concessions in wages and work conditions.

To impose a full measure of austerity upon workers and peasants, the ruling economic interests would have to abolish the democratic rights that helped the masses defend their modest living standards. The solution was to smash their unions, political organizations, and civil liberties. Industrialists and big landowners wanted someone at the helm who could break the power of organized workers and farm laborers and impose a stern order on the masses.

 For this task Benito Mussolini, armed with his gangs of Blackshirts, seemed the likely candidate. 



In 1922, the Federazione Industriale, composed of the leaders of industry, along with representatives from the banking and agribusiness associations, met with Mussolini to plan the "March on Rome," contributing 20 million lire to the undertaking. With the additional backing of Italy's top military officers and police chiefs, the fascist "revolution"-really a coup d'etat-took place. 

Within two years after seizing state power, Mussolini had shut down all opposition newspapers and crushed the Socialist, Liberal, Catholic, Democratic, and Republican parties, which together had commanded some 80 percent of the vote. Labor leaders, peasant leaders, parliamentary delegates, and others critical of the new regime were beaten, exiled, or murdered by fascist terror squadristi.

The Italian Communist party endured the severest repression of all, yet managed to maintain a courageous underground resistance that eventually evolved into armed struggle against the Blackshirts and the German occupation force.





Whom Did the Fascists Support? 


There is a vast literature on who supported the Nazis, but relatively little on whom the Nazis supported after they came to power. This is in keeping with the tendency of conventional scholarship to avoid the entire subject of capitalism whenever something unfavorable might be said about it. Whose interests did Mussolini and Hitler support?

 In both Italy in the 1920s and Germany in the 1930s, old industrial evils, thought to have passed permanently into history, re-emerged as the conditions of labor deteriorated precipitously. In the name of saving society from the Red Menace, unions and strikes were outlawed. Union property and farm cooperatives were confiscated and handed over to rich private owners. 

Minimum-wage laws, overtime pay, and factory safety regulations were abolished. 

Speedups became commonplace. Dismissals or imprisonment awaited those workers who complained about unsafe or inhumane work conditions. Workers toiled longer hours for less pay. The already modest wages were severely cut, in Germany by 25 to 40 percent, in Italy by 50 percent. In Italy, child labor was reintroduced. To be sure, a few crumbs were thrown to the populace.

 There were free concerts and sporting events, some meager social programs, a dole for the unemployed financed mostly by contributions from working people, and showy public works projects designed to evoke civic pride. Both Mussolini and Hitler showed their gratitude to their big business patrons by privatizing many perfectly solvent state-owned steel mills, power plants, banks, and steamship companies. Both regimes dipped heavily into the public treasury to refloat or subsidize heavy industry. 

Agribusiness farming was expanded and heavily subsidized. Both states guaranteed a return on the capital invested by giant corporations while assuming most of the risks and losses on investments. As is often the case with reactionary regimes, public capital was raided by private capital. At the same time, taxes were increased for the general populace but lowered or eliminated for the rich and big business. Inheritance taxes on the wealthy were greatly reduced or abolished altogether. 

The result of all this? In Italy during the 1930s the economy was gripped by recession, a staggering public debt, and widespread corruption. But industrial profits rose and the armaments factories busily rolled out weapons in preparation for the war to come. In Germany, unemployment was cut in half with the considerable expansion in armaments jobs, but overall poverty increased because of the drastic wage cuts. 

And from 1935 to 1943 industrial profits increased substantially while the net income of corporate leaders climbed 46 percent. 

During the radical 1930s, in the United States, Great Britain, and Scandanavia, upper-income groups experienced a 


modest decline in their share of the national income; but in Germany the top 5 percent enjoyed a 15 percent gain.5 Despite this record, most writers have ignored fascism's close collaboration with big business. Some even argue that business was not a beneficiary but a victim of fascism.

Angelo Codevilla, a Hoover Institute conservative scribe, blithely announced: "If fascism means anything, it means government ownership and control of business". 


Thus fascism is misrepresented as a mutant form of socialism. In fact, if fascism means anything, it means all-out government support for business and severe repression of antibusiness, prolabor forces." -Michael Parenti 

(https://eastsidemarxism.files.wordpress.com/2017/04/michael-parenti-blackshirts-and-reds-rational-fascism-and-the-overthrow-of-communism.pdf)



Please educate yourself, the actual link between Fascism and big Corporations is undeniable. They may don't believe in "Free-market Capitalism" but guess wha, the Big Corporations don't either.

Regardless, we can be dinosaurs living in the bush, big and ugly, biting the crap outta eachother and still have a massive rock nuke the existence outta our species. Or we can enjoy our "horrible" aircondition, automobile riding, ready made food and shelter civilization and still die either by our own hands, global damage or by whatever other theory out there. Or we live for billions until our sun dies. The end may come regardless but its definitely not because of civilization itself. Ultimately its all because of time. Time brings end to things. It wasn't because of fossil fuels that caused the warming. It happens naturally over millenia as earth wobbles on its y-axis. replies.text: @jedichild6815 if you look up the word dude it has tons of meanings to be quite honest. In Egypt it means camel penis in, in Australia it also means camel penis or for skin, in the US it was another term a Dandy a male who kept up with the fashions of the time in the 18th century  and in some parts of the world, the address the word to mean an ingrown or infected hair on an elephant or horse. So yeah I remember hearing the word used during that movie as well along with Michelle tanner from full house saying it too. But true origins of the word are up in the air on this debate. But most people say that it's definition for that of a Dandy man who is well dressed in the styles of fashion is the most widely accepted. But personally for me I found out that it's definition was towards that of the ingrown ass hair of a horse when I was younger from a teacher. So yeah that's why saying it has a gender association to being a male word doesn't make sense to me. Plus according to urban dictionary standards it's a word to address a friend/person which can mean anyone can be called "dude" male or female.

text: English is my third language. All this new useless terminology is a nightmare for me. I attended a advance life support training the other day. replies.author: @coffee_sploosh
replies.text:
@cowafungus8104 well, the answer is hidden behind what's actually propping these tiktoks up. The internet is building a simulated reality for people, even us but, most of us maintain some of our sanity, especially adults with real world responsibilities (not all). Kids and young adults without responsibility find pride and instant gratification in saying things that are being propped up by the controlled algorithm. It gives them a dopamine response. Its an algorithm designed to keep us packed away in our square little identitarian boxes, packed away in larger boxes, inside more and more boxes. All boxes are classified as a subgroup of the human race. When you shut those who run these companies down, in other words, when you throw away the screen, then you will find peace and, sanity would once again return to these people. Only after their withdrawals subside. I'm a firm believer that this is intentional. TikTok was "Made in China" afterall. Powers that be here in the West would LOVE to see identitarianism here, dividing all of us, and would absolutely love to see their power solidified with communism. Even the capitalists who are already extraordinarily wealthy. They don't want competition.. they'd murder to keep their wealth.. and that they do in communist states. 

But even I'm aware, I could be wrong. Years and year of watching these things unfold with a great deal of skepticism brought me to this conclusion.

Do you realize the implications of that truth tho? I think that means we will have to gain (notice I didn't say REgain) control of the government & pass a law that denies anyone younger than let's say 26 to participate in any form of online communication, especially politcal, but you'd probably have to keep them relegated to video games & documentaries & simple fun &/or informational videos. Unless there was a terrible war that destroyed our ability to have internet at all. Idk, I just don't know.... there's gotta be a way to fix this. This is me.  I got caught up in the LGBTQ+ community cuz my friends went way left and I was still struggling with my mental health and unable to think on my own.

After a few years of identifying as trans or genderqueer/ non-binary/ whatever, I just ended up confused.
This past year (so starting a bit after turning 25 in March last year) I began understanding myself as a woman, the female human I am and was since I was first developed in my mom‚Äôs womb.
I‚Äôve gotten better at being glad I‚Äôm a lady and using my given name (a form of it) but when people ask pronoun preferences for me, I still hesitate before saying she/her.

I have even found research/studies that report many girls don‚Äôt feel comfortable in their bodies as women until mid-late twenties.

I hated my feminine body but now I love it.

Will say tho: while I don‚Äôt miss the days of stressing about bathrooms, I do kinda miss the acceptance and being lifted up by the seemingly overwhelmingly numerous people who will probably hate me for being a person who can think now.

replies.author: @RoganGunn
replies.text:
@danwhiffen9235 Spot on mate. Communes only work when you have a small group, say a family group bound by blood ties, and they do not work at scale.

There was a time when hippy communes were a thing; it was called the Neolithic Agricultural Revolution, and it was back breaking work for little immediate gain. We have archaeological evidence where you can see the damage to skeletons due to the heavy labour and poor nutrition from only eating grains. 

By contrast, their hunter-gatherer contemporaries had quite healthy physiology due to living in man's natural environment. They probably thought the farmers were mad, to the point that paleoanthropologists now believe the agricultural revolution was catalysed by an extreme religious belief system, as there was no clear benefit to it at first. However, they had more children than the hunters, to work to the farms and overcome the increased child mortality, and they eventually learned to farm better, domesticated livestock etc, therefore their numbers grew slowly and they spread out, and their religious ideology spread with them.

Eventually larger settlements were established, food surpluses were achieved and populations grew faster, property rights and the division of labour became a thing, and life started to improve. Chieftains and social hierarchies started to develop at this time, leading to the first towns and cities, and to writing, money and civilisation.

The only way that society can exist at scale is through division of labour mediated by free economic exchange - capitalism. It took us 10,000 years or so to figure this out, now these kids are like, "I've got a *better* idea! You know all those murderous dictators in the 20th Century? They weren't doing it right, but if you put ME in charge..." ü§™
